title: I only started watching pro lol recently.?
body: has it always been like this. the same 15 champions being picked in every match. tower sieging. lane swapping. barely any team fighting. the only time teams TEAM FIGHT is when someone either fucks up or the other team is simply way ahead. or poor draft. I mean i watched some of last year worlds recently and it seemed a lot different tbh. a lot of champions. that I would never imagine getting picked. were picked. I mean is it just the way the game shifted or what. every time I watch the best part is champ select pick bans to see if someone is gonna pick a differrent champion but no. same champs. its just really lame.

Why is it lame that they play a strategy game like its a strategy game?

Just because most people in soloq play this game like its team death match doesn't mean that's the way it was meant to be played.

The reason a lot of games end up playing out so similarly is because teams are competing to execute what they consider to be the best strategies in the actual games that matter.

I bet their scrims where they actually try out new strats and try to innovate would be more interesting to watch but making that available would give away strategies for them to their opponents which would be pretty unfair.

Well, that's how I want to play in my ranked games but it seems like people just about go all-in whenever they see an opponent like loose cannon.

Yes, I appreciate how the pros play.

thats not my point here. am saying is why not more champions are viable?. well there is definitely a reason for that but every champion should be viable.

Most champions are viable, but you better contrast between organized pro play and solo q. Most things develop in rankeds and find their way into the lcs and other pro series if considered powerful enough, like Zzrot Udyr or Runeglaive Ezreal. 

For them, it's all about efficiency and coordination, for us ranked player, it's all about comfort picks and carry potential, as we usually don't talk with our team. So stuff like Jungle Shyvana and Trynd Top are perfectly viable for us. But these picks don't fit into the pro play strategy books, so it's unlikely to ever see them in near future.
Most champions are viable, but are not th best choices. Only the best choices matter.

They're playing for money rather than fun so they can't really afford to mess around with the picks. It's not that they're aren't other champions they can play, it's just that they're not willing to risk it. The same could be said for any 'sport' really. is it 'possible' for a football team to only call wildcat plays and win? Sure. But they do what has the best chance of winning. The enjoyment of the game comes from watching the strategy and the different playstyles, which when you watch enough becomes pretty distinct between the regions and teams within those regions.

Diversity in pro picks has been an issue since at least season 3. Pros find the small handful of champs that are strong and have the least amount of counterplay, and spam them to hell and back. I'm not doubting them for doing that, the whole point for them is to win. But it does get boring quickly watching the same section of champs over and over and over and over again.

There was actually a discussion here with a Rioter last year about this very topic. He seemed to be interested in the suggestion that in a pro tourney, once a champion was picked a certain number of times, it would be disabled for the rest of the tourney. That would essentially force diversity on the pros and open up a large section of the roster as possible picks.

Of course there are many negatives to that as well, and as we see nothing came of that discussion. But it is telling that Riot knows watching the same champions in the same matchups constantly isn't doing them any favors.
IN S5 the situation about pro pick diversity was decent though, at S5 Worlds you had like 55+ champs played/banned throughout the entire tournament, this season is actually worse than usual

S5 is the exception rather than the usual. Cinderhulk made tanks popular near mid season, allowing a tank meta to set in and open up all kinds of picks. Granted, cinderhulk and tanks were mysteriously nerfed right before worlds started up, but the meta didn't change overnight so we ended up seeing more diversity because of that.

And how sad is it that we consider 55/12X champs to be a "decent diversity". It's less than half. Take away the ten or so champs that only got picked/banned once (say if a team had already locked in their spot and started playing champs just for fun), and we're down even further. 80 would be a decent diversity. 100 would be a dream.

This season has probably been the most diverse when it comes to champion picks. However, there is always weeks where there are the most contested picks (i.e. Alistar or Braum in support).

This season specifically has a meta where teams ALWAYS lane swap, top laners usually double jungle, and supports may late invade to disrupt the first jungle clear. There are a handful of reasons but basically...
1. ADC and support take jungle camp to get the unfair level 2 spike (usually this would be the side of double golems.
2. This causes the jungle to start on the opposite side (very predictable)
3. This causes top laner to stay w/ their jungler for protection AND because top laner will get zoned out of CS/XP in the 2v1 against the ADC/Support
4. Turrets are so easy to take early game which leads to maybe a 3 or 4 man push. This also leads to a game of chicken where basically the first team to stop pushing loses out on more turrets/xp/CS
5. Dragon isn't as important so there aren't fights for it unless it's easy to take

Every season (or parts of the season) have specific metas that the pros will follow (because it's the 'best/efficient' way to play). We've had some metas where you have 50+ minute games regularly. Some seasons have games that are decided during the first 15 minutes and end by 25-30 minutes. Some seasons where there are 6 junglers banned every game (a bit of hyperbole). 

This season is definitely boring for the first 15 minutes unless you're interested in the mind games and strategies of working the map and lanes. This season ALSO has the most interesting since you could see 3 markmen on 1 team, lots of assassins, or lots of tanks (long intricate teamfights). We definitely have seen some crazier off-meta picks (Huni on Cho'Gath, Adrian on Soraka, Alex Ich on mid Nautilus, etc).

I think it's more the fact that most pros are really good at 2-3 champions at most. I don't watch much LCS but from what I know most pro players have a couple of comfort picks they can really really well and are pretty much meh to okay level on everything else.
